editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Â¶ To the louynge Reader.
div.p:
IOÅ¿ephus, the true HyÅ¿toriographe (gentle reader) hathe wrytten in his firÅ¿t boke of the Judaical hyÅ¿tories yâ¢ the fyrÅ¿t inueÌters of AÅ¿tronomy, and the inquiÅ¿itours of the courÅ¿e and celeÅ¿tiall mouementes haue bene the Å¿onnes of Seth who wylling to leaue Å¿ome memory therof vnto their chyldren and poÅ¿teritye, dyd ordayne and make two great pillers, the one of earth beyng harde dried, and the other of Copper, in the whyche they dyd graue the prynciples of the Å¿euen Artes liberall, and eÅ¿pecially that of AÅ¿trologie. And they wrote the Å¿ame in the Å¿ayd pillers, to thende that if the worlde Å¿houlde periÅ¿he by fier, or by water, (as they dyd
vnderÅ¿tande of their good father Seth: who had learned the Å¿ame of Adam) that then one of the Å¿ayde pillers Å¿houlde abyde whole, and that the Scyence of AÅ¿tronomie Å¿houlde not periÅ¿he. Some do affirme that Abraham dyd firÅ¿t find it, other Å¿aye that it was MoyÅ¿es, Dyodore Sicilian Å¿ayeth, that the Egiptyans were the firÅ¿te Authors, and Herodote wryteth that the Phenicians wer the inuenters, but who Å¿o euer they were, it lyttle forceth, let vs therefore leaue the inquiÅ¿ition vnto the curious and praiÅ¿e we God the creatoure of his diuine grace, who hath willed to illuminate the vnderÅ¿tanding of them whiche haue left vs in writing the art of AÅ¿tronomie, to our great commoditie and profyt. And Å¿einge that the people at thys preÅ¿ente are dayly more intentiue, & enclined alÅ¿o to reade &
to haue vnderÅ¿tandynge in artes and Å¿ciences, as Å¿ome which do folowe polletycke and cyuell matters, do applie them Å¿elues to vnderÅ¿taÌd the lawes of Cities, and Regions, and of Å¿uch thynges as apperteyne vnto the feates of war. Other there be whiche gyue theÌ Å¿elues to read the holly Å¿criptures according to the vnderÅ¿tandynge of holy Church, to thende that thereby they maye be Å¿tirred and brought to lyue more vertuouÅ¿ly: and if ther be any which other wiÅ¿e do, we ought to pray vnto God that he wold in Å¿uche wiÅ¿e amende theim, that they take not his holy word in vaine: other ther bee whyche are deÅ¿irous to reade HiÅ¿tories & PoeÅ¿ies, and Å¿ome haue affection to read bookes of AÅ¿trologye, & to haue knowledge of the celeÅ¿tiall conÅ¿tellacions, & mouements, vnto whom thys preÅ¿ente
treatiÅ¿e of the rules & documents of the comon Almanackes named Ephemerides (tranÅ¿lated into engliÅ¿he) Å¿hal be right expedient & neceÅ¿Å¿ary, Å¿eing yt theÅ¿e rules are the pathe & way vnto the knowledge of the Å¿aid Ephemerides, for by theÌ are fouÌd the courÅ¿e, & mouemeÌts of the lightes and planets, wyth other neceÅ¿Å¿ary thinges of AÅ¿trology wherby to iudge & PrognoÅ¿ti eate of the whether, and of things to come, as by the table folowing more plainly doth appere. Take therefore in good worthe (louing Reader) theÅ¿e few rules, being my firÅ¿t traduction, & loke Å¿hortely if God Å¿pare me life for other workes apperteining vnto this worthye Arte.

div.head: Â¶ Of thynges conteyned at the begynnyng and entring of the Ephemerides The firÅ¿t Rule, or Canon.
div.p:
FOR to haue cleare, and eaÅ¿ye vnderÅ¿tandynge of the vÅ¿e, and practyÅ¿e of the Ephemerides, in leuynge all Å¿uperfluous thynges & wordes, it is conuenient firÅ¿t to note that at the begynnynge: and entrynge of euerye Ephemerides, is wrytten the yeare for the whyche it Å¿erueth, and apperteyneth, and after there foloweth the common thynges of the eccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall compoÅ¿t and kalender, that is too Å¿aye, the circle of the moone, called the golden nombre, the circle of the Å¿unne, the Dominicall letter, and the Indyction Romane, called in latten Indictio Romana, wyth the monthes and dayes,
vpon the whyche the mouable feaÅ¿tes in that yeare maye be celebrated accordyng to their order.

AFterwardes doth followe vnderneth the Å¿aide eclipÅ¿e, the time pr â¢

After you Å¿hal Å¿ubÅ¿tra the
mouemente from the greateÅ¿t: and that whiche doth remayne Å¿halbe the mouement of the Å¿ayd plan â¢â¢ e anÅ¿wering vnto the Å¿ame natural daye, froÌ one noone tide to the other, the whyche mouement you Å¿hall deuide byâª 24. in reÅ¿oluinge the degrees into minutes, and the minutes into Å¿econdes, if there be nede, then thou Å¿halt adde Å¿o manye times the. 24. parte of the Å¿ayd dayly mouemeÌt vnto the mouement of the nonetide paÅ¿t, as there be howers paÅ¿t Å¿ince the Å¿ame nonetide, yf the planet be direct. Or els you Å¿hal Å¿ubÅ¿tra the Å¿ame. 24. parte Å¿o many times if he be retrograde, & if you haue one quarter, one third, or halfe of an houre more: you maye likewiÅ¿e adde or Å¿ubÅ¿traye the fourth, or the thirde, or the halfe of the aboue Å¿ayd. 24. parte of the Å¿ayd dayly mouemeÌt and by this meane you Å¿hal haue that which you demaund.

div.head: Â¶ For to bringe the true mouement of the moone vnto what meridiane you pleaÅ¿e. 9. rule.
div.p:
ANd although that the Ephemerides laÅ¿t imprinted, are calculated and reduced vnto the meridiane of a Citie of Almaigne called Tubinge, yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e
it is no neede to reduce, or briÌg the true places & mouemeÌtes of the Å¿unne and of the. 5. planetes (whiche are Å¿lowe inoughe of mouement) vnto anye other meridiane what Å¿o euer it be: except onely the place of the moone, for the Å¿wiftnes of his mouement. The whiche you Å¿hall do after this maner. Take the name of your city, or of ye place moÅ¿t nereÅ¿t to the Å¿ame, in the table which is called Tabula regionum, prouinciarum, et oppidorum inÅ¿igniorum Europae. and drawinge toward the right hande, you Å¿hal finde vnder the charecter of the moone the numbre of minutes, which muÅ¿t be added or Å¿ubÅ¿traed from the true mouemente of the Å¿aid moone, which hath bene calculated by the Å¿ayd Ephemerides: accordinge as the letter. A. or. M. being at the left hand Å¿hal Å¿hewe you, for the letter. A. Å¿ignifyeth that ye muÅ¿t adde, and the letter. M. that you muÅ¿t dimyniÅ¿he or Å¿ubÅ¿tra the Å¿ayde minutes, and therewith you Å¿hall finde al at once at the right hande of the Å¿ayd minutes, in the laÅ¿te columpne, the degrees of the latitude, or eleuatioÌ of the pole Articke of the Å¿ayd citie or region, of the which you may haue to do withal as here after you Å¿hal Å¿ee.

The which dominations wheÌ they do chauÌge are likewiÅ¿e noted by the chauÌge of ye Å¿ayd capital letters put or Å¿et amoÌg the noumbers of the true mouementes. As if ouer the head you haue. S. A. and then you mete belowe vnderneth in any of the colomnes, this letter. D. it betokeneth yâ¢ the planet which was Å¿eptentrional

S. which is a thing righte eaÅ¿y to be vnderÅ¿tande, we call the planet deÅ¿cendant, whan the centre of his epicicle, deÅ¿ceÌdeth from the point of the eccentrike the moÅ¿t fartheÅ¿t parte of the earth whyche is called Axe tree, towardes hys oppoÅ¿ite whych is the moÅ¿t neareÅ¿t and is called aÅ¿cendant, when from the Å¿aid point oppoÅ¿yte he mounteth towardes the Å¿ayd poynt moÅ¿t fartheÅ¿t of the earth.

div.head: Of the Latytude of the moone. the. 11.
div.p: THe latitude of the moone, is founde in the Å¿ayde Ephemerides by his owne table intituled Tabula latitudiais lunae thus as foloweth. Take the true mouement of the mone, & of the dragons head. â of the Å¿ame, at the day and hower propoÅ¿ed as hath bene Å¿aid hereto fore: and reÅ¿olue the caracters of the Å¿ygnes of the Å¿ame mouemeÌts into the nombers of the Å¿aide Å¿ignes whiche are theÅ¿e that folowe.

Â¶ Then Å¿ubÅ¿tra the true mouemente of the head of the dragon of the moone, froÌ his owne proper and true mouement in adding. 12. Å¿ignes if the Å¿ubÅ¿tcaction caÌ not be otherwiÅ¿e made) and that whyche reÅ¿teth, Å¿hal be the true argument of the latitude of the moone, with the which argumente you Å¿hall enter the table of the latitude of the Å¿ame in taking the noumber of the Å¿ignes of the Å¿ayde argument at the head of the Å¿ayde table, and the de, grees at the lefte Å¿ide, in the line intituled linea numeri, which procede in deÅ¿cending from the toppe downeward or els in taking the nomber of the Å¿ignes at the foote of the Å¿ayde table, and the degrees at the right hand in the line which amouÌ teth from beneth vpwarders: for in the place at the which yâ¢ lines of the noÌbers of the Å¿ayd Å¿ignes & degrees do agree together, you Å¿hall find the latitude of the moone in degrees & minutes, the which latitude Å¿hall be called Å¿eptentrionall, if you haue taken the nombers of the Å¿ygnes at the head of the table, or els meridionall
if the Å¿aide Å¿ignes haue bene taken at the foote of the table. And further the moone Å¿halbe called aÅ¿cendant if the nuÌ bre of the Å¿ignes of the argument of the latitude be. 0. or. 1. or. 2. in the head, and. 9 or. 10. or. 11. at the foote of the Å¿aide table And if the Å¿aide nombre of Å¿ignes aboue Å¿aide bee in the heade. 3. or. 4. or. 5. and at the foote. 6. 7. or. 8. Å¿he Å¿hall be named deÅ¿cendant as the titles and inÅ¿criptions of the Å¿aid table doth declare, being Å¿ecur yâ¢ head & fote of euery coluÌne of the Å¿ame Â¶ And if it happen that your argument haue any nombre of minutes ouer & beÅ¿ides the degrees, it behoueth to enter the Å¿ayd table two times, & to take firÅ¿te the latitude whiche aunÅ¿wereth vnto the degrees precedinge immediatlye the Å¿ayd minutes, and then the latitude aunÅ¿wering vnto the degrees which next do folowe the Å¿aid minutes. After it is coÌuenient to take the difference of both the latitudes in Å¿ubÅ¿traing the leaÅ¿t from the greateÅ¿t. That done put. 60. for the firÅ¿t nombre, & the nombre of the Å¿ayd minutes for the Å¿econd, and the Å¿aid difference for the third: and multiply the third noÌ bre by the Å¿econde, and that whiche cometh of the multiplication deuide by the
firÅ¿t & you Å¿hal haue the fourth noumbre proportionall, the whiche you muÅ¿t adde vnto the firÅ¿t latitude, yf it be leÅ¿Å¿e then the Å¿econd: or els Å¿ubÅ¿tra the Å¿ame from the Å¿ayd firÅ¿t latitude, if it do Å¿urmounte the Å¿ecoÌd latitude for that which cometh or remayneth therof Å¿hal be the true latitude of the moone anÅ¿wering vnto the minutes of the Å¿ayd argument.

And who that would make Å¿horte, there is no daunger if he leaue the Å¿ayd minutes if they be leÅ¿Å¿e then. 30, or els to adde one degre vnto the degrees of the Å¿ayde argument, if the Å¿ayde minute do excede or paÅ¿Å¿e 30. and then to finde the latitude as aboue hath bene Å¿ayd.

div.head: Of the aÅ¿pectes of the moone vnto the Å¿unne and planetes, & other thinges conteyned in the righte and Å¿econde face of the Å¿aide Ephemerides the. 12. rule.
div.p:
ConÅ¿equently in the right and Å¿econd face of the Å¿aide Ephemerides, are comprehended the aÅ¿pectes of the moone vnto the Å¿unne, and vnto the. 5. planetes, and from one of the planets vnto the other: as the Å¿uperÅ¿cription of the Å¿aid face doth Å¿hewe. And firÅ¿te of al is declared the

â¹. Signifieth Å¿extile aÅ¿pecte: whiche is cauÅ¿ed, by the diÅ¿taunce of two Å¿ygnes betwene two planettes. And it is Å¿oo named, by cauÅ¿e two Å¿ygnes doo make the Å¿yxte parte of the. 12. Å¿ignes of the Å¿ayde zodiacke, and it is too bee noted, that the nomber Å¿ette after the character of eueri aÅ¿pecte Å¿heweth the howre in the whyche the Å¿ayde aÅ¿pecte Å¿hall happen in reckenyng from the noonetide of the Å¿ame day righ â¢â¢ with the whiche is noted the Å¿aide aÅ¿pecte. Excepte the coniunctions and oppoÅ¿itions of the moone and of the Å¿unne, that is to Å¿aye the newe and full moones of the whyche not onely the howres, but alÅ¿o the mynutes are written for the firÅ¿t nombre after the carrecter of the coÌiunction or oppoÅ¿ition of the Å¿unne and of the moone, do Å¿ignifye the howre: and the Å¿econde and ryghte nombre, the mynutes that the Å¿aid coniunctions, or oppoÅ¿itions Å¿hall fall vpon.

div.head: Howe the newe and full mones, and eclypÅ¿es, maye be reduced vnto what meridiane you will, differynge from the Å¿ame of the Ephemeridesâª The. 13.
div.p: FOr Å¿o muche that the Å¿ayde new and full moones, and the eclypÅ¿es of the Å¿unne and of the moone, whiche happen in theim, are calculated in the Å¿ayde Ephemerides for the meridiane of the afore named cytie of Tubinge in Almaigne: it is conueniente â¢â¢ reduce, for the leÅ¿te, the tyme of the Å¿ayde coniunctions, oppoÅ¿itions, and eclypÅ¿es of the Å¿unne and of the moone vnto your meridiane, wytheoute hauynge care of the other aÅ¿pectes the whyche you Å¿hall eaÅ¿elye doo by the table entituled Tabularegionum, prouinciarum, et oppidorum inÅ¿ignioruÌ europae thus as followeth.

Take the name of youre Citye, or of the place moÅ¿t neareÅ¿t to the Å¿ame, in the table aboue Å¿ayde, & you Å¿hal fynd at the ryghte Å¿yde vnder this tittle Tempus, the howers and mynutes, or the mynutes onely, whiche you muÅ¿t adde, or Å¿ubÅ¿tra â¢ rom the howres and minutes of the Å¿aid coniunctions, and oppoÅ¿itions, and eclipÅ¿es of the Å¿unne and of the moone: as the â¢ ettre A. or M. written at the lefte Å¿yde of â¢ he Å¿ayde howres and mynutes Å¿hall
Å¿hewe you.

div.head: Of the aÅ¿pectes of the Å¿unne vnto the planettes, and of the planettes amonge theim Å¿elues, and of the dragon of the moone. The. 14.
div.p: AFterwarde there foloweth vpon the ryghte Å¿yde of the Å¿ayde face of the Ephemerides, the aÅ¿pectes of the Å¿unne vnto the planettes, and of one planet vnto a nother, whiche are figured as well by the carracters of the Å¿ayde plannettes, as by the characters of the Å¿ayde aÅ¿pectes, of the which the interpretation hathe beene heretofore declared. ConÅ¿equently amonge the Å¿aide aÅ¿pectes is noted when the moone is in the head or in the tayle of the dragon, whiche are their interÅ¿ections or diuiÅ¿ions of his circle and of the Zodiake, as we haue Å¿aid a â¢ fore. div.head: Â¶ When the planets are oriental or occidental. 15. rule.
div.p: FInally is noted ouer the head of euery columpne of the. 5. planets, vnder their propre charecters, when the Å¿ayd planets are orientall or occidentall by theÅ¿e Å¿illables. or. and. oc. and it is to be noted that Å¿aturne, Iupiter and mars, are orientall whiles the Å¿unne departeth froÌ them after the couiunction of him and of the Å¿ayd planets, comminge vnto the oppoÅ¿ition and occidentall, from the Å¿aid oppoÅ¿ition in approchinge him Å¿elfe nere vnto them, vntill the coniunction nexte enÅ¿uing. But Venus and mercury are called orientall, when they do precedeâª the Å¿unne from the eaÅ¿t parte, and are Å¿eene before the Å¿unne riÅ¿ing and occidentall, when they do folowe the Å¿unne from the weÅ¿t parte, and are Å¿eene after the Å¿unne is Å¿ette.

div.head: For to knowe the quantitie of the artificial daye and of the nighte, and at what houre the Å¿unne ryÅ¿ethe and Å¿etteth. 16. rule
div.p:
ANd too the ende that all menne maye knowe, if they canne Å¿ee the eclipÅ¿es of the Å¿unne or of the moone which happen nere vnto the horizont
aboute the Å¿unne Å¿ettinge, or the Å¿un riÅ¿inge, it is neceÅ¿Å¿arye to knowe the quaÌ titie of the dayes and of the nightes artificiall, and at what howre the Å¿unne ryÅ¿eth and Å¿etteth. There is than before the table of the Ephemerides, a table intituled Tabula quantitatis dierum, that is to Å¿aye a table of the quantitye of the dayes: the whyche conteyneth in the hedde the latitudes, or eleuations of the pole of al places vpon the earth, from. 36. degrees, vntill. 55. degrees: and at the left hand there are. 6. Å¿ygnes of the zodiack & other. 6. at the righte hande, whyche are diÅ¿tributed from. 3. degrees to. 3. in the middes of the Å¿ayd table are comprehended the houres and mynutes of the halfe of an artificial daye, whyche are from the Å¿unne riÅ¿yng vntyll noonetide, or from noonetide vntyl the Å¿unne Å¿ettyng, when the Å¿unne is in the Å¿ignes Å¿eptrentionalles: or eles the howres & minutes of half of the nyghte whyche are from the Å¿unne Å¿ettynge vntyll mydnyghte, or from mydnyghte vntyll the Å¿unne ryÅ¿yng, whan the Å¿oÌne is in the Å¿ygnes meridionalles, knowe then in what Å¿igne, and degree the Å¿unne is, and howe muche the poole is eleuated aboue your horizont, as before hath be â¢
Å¿ayd.
And take the Å¿ayde Å¿ygne and degre at the ryghte, or lefte Å¿yde of the aboue Å¿ayde table, and procede ryghtelye in the Å¿ame table, vntyll that you be â¢ uÅ¿telye at the nombre of youre pole: and there you Å¿hall finde the howers, and minutes of the halfe of the artificiall day if the Å¿unne be in the Å¿eptentrionall parte of the zodiacke: or elles of the haife of the nyghte, if he bee in the meridionall parte: what Å¿ygnes are Å¿eptentrionalles, and what meridionals hath beene declared in the fifte Rule. The whiche is likewiÅ¿e euident by the Å¿ayde table, by theÅ¿e woordes, Sigâª Bor. fig. AuÅ¿t. Yf you double then, the Å¿ayde howres and minuttes of the halfe of the artificiall daye, you Å¿hall haue the whole day: and if you do Å¿ubÅ¿tra them from. 24. howres, there reÅ¿teth the nyghte. Or yf you double the howres and mynutes of the halfe of the nyghte, you Å¿hall haue the nyghte wholye: and if you Å¿ubÅ¿tra them from. 24. howres, there reÅ¿tethe the artyfyciall day, and by thys meanes you maye knowe at what howre the Sunne ryÅ¿ethe, or Å¿ettethe euerye daye in the yeare.

For the daye artificial dureth from the Å¿unne riÅ¿inge to noone, vntill the Å¿unne Å¿etting: and the night artificial, from the Å¿unne Å¿etting vnto midnight, and Å¿o vntil the Å¿unne riÅ¿ing. And the natural day of. 24. houres dothe comprehend them both.

div.head: Â¶ Of the, 12. houÅ¿es of heauen, and of their nature accidentall accordinge vnto the iudgement of the aÅ¿trologians. 17. rule.
div.p:
FOr to gather any Å¿ruyt of the thynges aboueÅ¿ayd according to the habilitie that god hath geuen vnto meÌ it is conuenient, to treat of the. 12. houÅ¿es of heauen, and of their accidentiall nature and how they muÅ¿t be diÅ¿tingued and erected in all regions. In leauinge then a heape of Å¿uperfluous and vnprofitable wordes, whiche are in the latine rules of the Ephemerides and the varietis of the opinions of the AÅ¿trologians touching the Å¿aid houÅ¿es, I wil declare the opinion and maner howe to do them, according vnto the which, the Tables are calculated which are in the Ephemerides, and that all men do commenlye vÅ¿e now adayes. To come then vnto the
poynt you muÅ¿te note that as the Å¿unne and the moone and the. 5. planettes, makinge their reuolution by their propre mouementes vnder the Zodiake, doo cauÅ¿e diuers effectes and Å¿enÅ¿ible mutacions in earthly thinges, according vnto the diuers proiection of their beames and diuers diÅ¿poÅ¿itions of natural thinges here belowe, in makinge their peregrinacion from Å¿igne to Å¿igne, and according vnto the nature accidentale, of the 12. Å¿ignes of the Zodiake: likewiÅ¿e the Å¿ayd lightes and planetes, in tourninge round about the earthe by the firÅ¿te and vniuerÅ¿al mouement of al the world, froÌ the orient by the Å¿outh into the accident, within the time and Å¿pace of. 24. houres (whiche we cal a natural daye) do cauÅ¿e again euery day of the yeare diuers and perticuler effectes, according as they be in the orient or occident, and notably eleuated or depreÅ¿Å¿ed vnder yâ¢ earth, & yâ¢ thei haue more Å¿tronge or weake irradiacioÌ vppon the Å¿ayde thinges here belowe on earth. For this cauÅ¿e the AÅ¿trologians haue diÅ¿tingued all the roundnes of the vniuerÅ¿all worlde into. 12. partes (after the nombre of the Å¿aid. 12. Å¿ignes) whych are called houÅ¿es, of the which there are
6. aboue the earth, and. 6. vnderneth parpetually and in all regions, in the maner and forme as foloweth.

FirÅ¿t it is to vnderÅ¿tande, that the meridian circle and the Horizont, do deuide them Å¿elues into 2. halfes, and with right angles towardes the South and North, and they deuide the Equinoctiall into 4. quarters, whereof there be. 2. aboue the earth, and 2. vnderneth: two lykewiÅ¿e toward the EaÅ¿t, and 2. toward the WeÅ¿t. And euery. 4. porcion contemeth. 90. degrees. You muÅ¿t theÌ imagen euery of the Å¿aid quarters of the equino. to be deuided into 3 egal parts of 30 degrees, euery one of them & by the pointes of the Å¿aid deuiÅ¿ions to paÅ¿Å¿e. 4. great circles, proceding froÌ the foreÅ¿aid interÅ¿ections of the meridian circle, & of yâ¢ horizont, by this menes the Å¿aid 4. circles with yâ¢ Å¿ayd meridian & horizont (which do make togither the nuÌ bre of. 6.) do deuid the equl. & al the Å¿phere of the world into. 12. partes, which we cal the. 1 â¢ . houÅ¿es of heauen: the which are or dained & diÅ¿tributed accordinge vnto the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of the 12. lines of the zodiacke & of the propre mouement of the lyghtes & planets, coÌtrary vnto the firÅ¿t mouemeÌt vniuerÅ¿all, as it doeth Å¿omwhat appeare by this fygure folowinge.

MYne opinion notwithÅ¿tandinge is, that the Å¿aide. 4. circles oughte to paÅ¿Å¿e by the deuiÅ¿yons of the Circle vertycall, whiche doth deuyde the meridian circle with right angles and not by the equinoctial (yf it be not in the right Sphere) for many good cauÅ¿es and inuincible reaÅ¿ons as is noted in the CoÅ¿mographie or Sphere of the worlde, publyÅ¿Å¿hed by Orentius, and in the. 12. Chapter of the Å¿econde boke of the Å¿ame.

Â¶ The firÅ¿t houÅ¿e beginneth then in the orientale parte of the horizont, and endeth in the next halfe circle which is vnder the Å¿aid horizont, the which houÅ¿e is named the angle of orient, or aÅ¿cendaunt, and horoÅ¿cope: and it is the houÅ¿e to iudge of all the beginninges of life, & the beginninges of all workes. For bycauÅ¿e the firÅ¿t and vniuerÅ¿al mouement beginneth at the eaÅ¿t parte, and rayÅ¿eth the Å¿terres and planets aboue the earth in Å¿uch wiÅ¿e that from the orient cometh all vertue and the heauenly goodnes.

The Å¿econd houÅ¿e foloweth after, vnder the Å¿aid horizont. The which is the houÅ¿e of Å¿ubÅ¿taunce as well of neceÅ¿Å¿ary thynges to the life, as of other goodes, of marchandiÅ¿es, of byinges, Å¿ellinges, adminiÅ¿trators, and helpers.

Â¶ The. 3. houÅ¿e folowinge endeth at the part of the meridiane, whyche is vnder the earthe, and bath Å¿ignification vppon brothers, and Å¿iÅ¿ters, couÅ¿ynes, neighbours and friendes, and vpon Å¿mal and Å¿hort viages.

Â¶ The. 4. houÅ¿e beginneth at the Å¿ayde parte of the meridiane, whiche is vnder the earth. The which is called the angle of the point of the earthe, or of midnight
and of Å¿ame the bottome or depth of heauen. And it is the houÅ¿e for to iudge of diuiÅ¿ions and heritages, of treaÅ¿ors hide and of all thynges vnmouable
The. 5. houÅ¿e foloweth after, the whyche is the houÅ¿e of chyldren, of frendÅ¿hippe legates and meÅ¿Å¿engers.

The. 6. and folowing houÅ¿e, is ended at the occidentall parte of the horizont and hath Å¿ignification vpon Å¿ickeneÅ¿Å¿es, lordeÅ¿hippes, membres of the body, vpon Å¿eruauntes, pryÅ¿oners, and domeÅ¿tycall beaÅ¿tes.

7. The Å¿euenth houÅ¿e begynneth at the Å¿aide horizonte occidentall drawynge toward the Å¿outh, called the angle or point of occident, oppoÅ¿ite vnto the aÅ¿cendant: whiche beginneth to deÅ¿cende vnder the horizont. And it is the houÅ¿e to iudge of women, mariages, debates and contentions, of the one halfe of the humaine lyfe.
8. The. 8. houÅ¿e foloweth after approching toward the South. The whiche is the houÅ¿e of death, and interfection, and of the ende of life.

9. The. 9. and houÅ¿e folowing is ended at the part of the meridiane which is aboue the earthe and hathe Å¿ignification vppon
long vÅ¿ages, peregrinations, fayth, religion, wiÅ¿edom, and dreames.

10. The tenthe houÅ¿e begynneth at the Å¿aide meridiane verticall aboue the earth the whyche called the angle or poynte of the Å¿outh, or of the middes of heauen, oppoÅ¿ite vnto the fourth houÅ¿e which is the angle of the earthe, and is the houÅ¿e royall, imperiall, of exaltacion, and honoure nobleneÅ¿Å¿e, and good renoume.
11. The eleuenthe houÅ¿e, foloweth affer, drawing towardes the EaÅ¿te, the whiche is the houÅ¿e for to iudge of hope, coÌfideÌce and the fortune of man.
12. The twelfe and laÅ¿t houÅ¿e, endinge at the oriente is the houÅ¿e of Å¿adnes, enuye, malice, deception and craft.

And by this maner there be foure angular and principall houÅ¿es, that is to Å¿aye the firÅ¿t, the fourth, the Å¿euenth, and the tenth. And foure whiche are named Å¿uccedinge, that is to Å¿aye. The Å¿econde, the fyfthe, the eyght, & the eleuenth, whiche do folowe the other foure aboueÅ¿ayd.

The other foure whiche come next after the Å¿uccedinge houÅ¿es, are called falling or coming after, which be theÅ¿e. The thirde, the Å¿ixt, the ninth, and the twelfth Of the whiche houÅ¿es this is the figurefolowing,
after the iudgemente of our AÅ¿trologians, and as they are accuÅ¿tomed to vÅ¿e them and to put them in platfourme.

div.p: And it is conueniente finallye, to note that the lyghtes and planettes do reioiÅ¿e, and haue certeyne power, and accidentall vertues, in Å¿ome houÅ¿es more then in other, as dothe heareafter folowe.

div.head: Â¶ Howe to erecte and diÅ¿tyngue the. 12. houÅ¿es of heauen, after the order of the Å¿ayd Ephemerides. 18. rule
div.p:
TO erect theÌ or caculate the. 12. houÅ¿es of heauen is no other thinge but to finde the pointes of the Zodiacke, which are noted and diÅ¿tingued by the Å¿ixe circles aboueÅ¿aid: the whiche you Å¿hall do by the tables of the Ephemerides thus as foloweth. You muÅ¿t theÌ firÅ¿t note, yâ¢ there are in the Å¿ayde Ephemerides
5. tables perticulers, Å¿ufficiente for all Europe, calculated for the latitude or eleuation of the poole of. 42. 45. 48. 51. and. 54. degrees. And althoughe that there be difference of. 2. degrees, betwen euerye of the Å¿aide eleuations or latitudes: yet can there folowe no notable erroure of the Å¿ame. If for the degrees left out you do vÅ¿e of the table whiche is calculated for the next degre. For the table of. 45. degrees Å¿hal Å¿erue principally for the Å¿ayde. 45. degrees: and without any notable errour for. 44. and. 46. and the Å¿ame of. 48. Å¿hall Å¿erue for. 47. and. 49. degrees and, Å¿o of the other. Comming then to the effect, you muÅ¿t conÅ¿ydre the time, at the which you will erect he Å¿aid houÅ¿es of heauen, to knowe if it be preciÅ¿ely at none, eyther before or after.

div.head: Â¶ The firÅ¿te parte or difference, when the time is preciÅ¿ely at noone
div.p:
LEt it be propoÅ¿ed that you woulde erect the Å¿ayde houÅ¿es at the houre of noone, preciÅ¿elye, you Å¿hall then take the true place and mouement of the
Å¿unne at the Å¿ayd houre of none by your Ephemerides. Then you Å¿hal take the Å¿igne in the which is the Å¿unne aboue the head of the Å¿ayd table of the houÅ¿es whiche is made, or may Å¿erue moÅ¿t commodiouÅ¿ly for your latitude or eleuation of the pole and the degree at the left haÌd of the Å¿ayd table: in the columne or line of the aboue Å¿ayd tenth houÅ¿e, for ye degre is the beginning of the 10 houÅ¿e. Right with the whiche degre, in drawing toward the ryght hand, you Å¿hal finde incontinent the degrees orderly of the. 11. 12. 1. 2. &. 3, houÅ¿e at the Å¿aid houre of noone. The whyche degrees are of the Å¿ignes, whoÅ¿e characters are nereÅ¿t noted aboue them. And if it happen that the true place & mouemeÌt of the Å¿unne haue anye nombre of minutes as moÅ¿t often it doth happeÌ then may you leaue thoÅ¿e minutes if they be leÅ¿Å¿e then. 30. or els adde one degree, if the Å¿aid nombre of minutes do excede. 30. without any errour, or notable intereÅ¿t.

div.head: Â¶ The maner how to proportionate the Å¿ayde houÅ¿es when the true place of the Å¿unne hath minutes.
div.p:
ANd if you wil haue the Å¿ayd houÅ¿es more curiouÅ¿ly: you Å¿hall doo thus. Take righte agaynÅ¿te the
whole degrees of the Å¿unne, whiche are before the minutes, the houÅ¿es whiche you Å¿hal finde at the right hand as I Å¿aid before. And at the left hande of the Å¿ayde houÅ¿es, take the time, that is to Å¿aye the houres and minutes, whiche you Å¿hall finde vnder this title Tempus a meridie.

Then take the difference of the Å¿aid time next enÅ¿uing (in Å¿ubÅ¿traing the leÅ¿Å¿er froÌ the greater, and note the Å¿ame a part vnder the Å¿ame time, LykewiÅ¿e take the difference of euery of the Å¿ayd houÅ¿es alredy noted & of the next houÅ¿es folowing, and note euery difference vnder his propre houÅ¿e. After this done, entre into the table entituled Tabula proportionuÌ ad 60. minuta celi domicilus fabricandis Å¿atiÅ¿faciens.

And take at the lefte Å¿ide of the Å¿ayde table the minutes of the true place of the Å¿unne whiche are ouer and beÅ¿ides the degrees, and at the head of the Å¿ame table take the nombre of the minutes of the Å¿ayd difference of time, and you Å¿hal finde right with thoÅ¿e minutes, the partes proportional of the Å¿ayd difference in Å¿econdes, or elles in minutes and Å¿econdes together. The which part proportionall, or the neareÅ¿t to the Å¿ame, you Å¿hall take at the left Å¿ide of the table folowing
the aboueÅ¿ayd, which is intituled Tabula quatuor minutorum temporis and the difference of euery houÅ¿e (the one after the other) at the heade of the Å¿ayde table: and youÅ¿hall finde righte againÅ¿te the Å¿ayde nombre the minutes, or the degrees and minutes together, the whiche you muÅ¿t adde vnto the degrees of the houÅ¿e, out of the whiche was taken the Å¿ayde difference, and there as the Å¿ayd houÅ¿es haue not the difference, you muÅ¿te adde nothinge vnto theym. By this meanes you Å¿hal haue the preciÅ¿e iuÅ¿tification of the Å¿ayd houÅ¿es more curious then neceÅ¿Å¿ary. Example. And for to haue of all more eaÅ¿ier vnderÅ¿tanding, I haue here giuen you an example, calculated for the middaye of the laÅ¿te of Jnue. 1540. and for the latitude of. 48. degrees, as is the Å¿ame of Paris. At the which tyme I did finde the Å¿unne to be in the. 17. degres and. 40. minutes of Cancer. And then I did execute and folowe the reÅ¿t, as aboue hath bene Å¿aide, and I haue taken in the Å¿ayd table proportionall at the left hand the. 40. minutes of the true place, & the 4. minutes of the difference of time at the heade of the Å¿ayde table, and right againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e I found. â¢ . minutes and. 40
Å¿econdes: whiche is the parte proporcionall of the Å¿aid difference of time, whiche was founde of the. 4. minutes, vnder Å¿uche reaÅ¿on as haue the. 40. minutes vnto 60. minutes of one hole houre. Afterwardes I did take in the Å¿aid table quatuor minutorum temporis, the Å¿aid. 2. minutes and 40. Å¿econdes at the right Å¿yde, and the difference of the howÅ¿es (whiche is but of one degree, at the head of the Å¿aide table: and I did finde right with them. 40. minutes to be added vnto euery houÅ¿e aunÅ¿wering vnto the 17 degrees of the Å¿uÌne: The which 40 minutes haue Å¿uche reaÅ¿on vnto one degree (whiche are worthe 60 minutes) as haue the 2 minutes and 40 Å¿econdes, vnto the aboue Å¿ayde 4 minutes of the difference of time), and by this meanes you do anoide a multiplication and diuiÅ¿ion by the Å¿aide table proportionall, and as muche by the table quatuor minutorum temporis, beÅ¿ides the reductions whiche Å¿houlde be made.
The reÅ¿te is cleare ynoughe by the diÅ¿cours, and Å¿upputation of the Å¿aid example propoÅ¿edâª of the which here foloweth the true deÅ¿cription.

div.head: Â¶ The Å¿econde parte or difference, when the time propoÅ¿ed is after none.
div.p:
ANd yf the time propoÅ¿ed be after noneâª you Å¿hall take the Å¿igne and degree that the Å¿unne is in, by the eight rule, and you Å¿hall enter into the table of the houÅ¿es of your region, as before hath ben Å¿ayde, taking the degree of the Å¿unne vnder the Å¿igne in the columne of the tenth houÅ¿e, and note apart the houres and minutes of the time, whiche you
Å¿hall finde at the lefte Å¿ide of the Å¿ayd degre. And if there be minutes beÅ¿ydes the degrees, you Å¿hall take the difference of the Å¿ayde time, and of the time next folowinge, and the parte proportional of the Å¿ame difference, by the aboueÅ¿aid table, intituled, tabula proportionum ad 60 minut â¢ . &c. with the Å¿ayd difference, and the minutes of the Å¿unne. The whiche part proportionall you Å¿hall adde vnto the Å¿ayde time which was taken right againÅ¿t the degree of the Å¿udne. Then afterward vnto yâ¢ time Å¿o iuÅ¿tified, you Å¿hall adde your time which is paÅ¿t after none, the minutes with the minutes, & the houres with the houres, in addinge for 60 minutes one houre vnto the Å¿ayd houres, the whiche houres if they do paÅ¿Å¿e 24, you muÅ¿te Å¿ubÅ¿tra them, and note the reÅ¿t. LikewiÅ¿e as many times as you Å¿hall haue 6 houres after noone, you Å¿hall adde vnto the Å¿aide time one minute, by this meanes you Å¿hall haue the time iuÅ¿ti â¢ ied for to fynde youre houÅ¿es. Then take the Å¿ayde tyme at the lefte Å¿yde of the table of the houÅ¿es, vnder the title, tempus a meridie, or the mooÅ¿t neareÅ¿t vnto it (yf you fynd not the Å¿ame preciÅ¿ely) and you Å¿hall finde at the right hand of yâ¢ Å¿aid time the 6 houÅ¿es
orientalles aboue Å¿ayd, as you may Å¿e by the example whiche foloweth, calculated for 8 houres after none of the Å¿aide laÅ¿te daye of June 1540, and for the aboue Å¿aid latitude of 48 degrees, the Å¿unne beynge then in the 17 degree and 59 minutes of Cancer.

div.head: Â¶ The thirde parte or difference when the time propoÅ¿ed is before none.
div.p:
IF the time propoÅ¿ed be before none, there Å¿hall be no difference or other difficultie to calculate, except that you muÅ¿t Å¿ubÅ¿tra the time that you do adde when it is after none. Then after that you Å¿hall haue taken the true place of the Å¿unne, and haue proportioned the time aunÅ¿weringe vnto the degree of the Å¿unne, as before hath ben Å¿aid
you Å¿hall Å¿ubÅ¿tra from the Å¿aide time, the diÅ¿taunce of the time propoÅ¿ed vntyll none, and as many minutes as the Å¿ayde diÅ¿taunce Å¿hall haue of times 6 howres, (in puttinge therunto 24 houres, yf the Å¿ayde Å¿ubÅ¿traction cannot otherwiÅ¿e be made) and with that whiche Å¿hall reÅ¿te of the Å¿ayde time, you Å¿hall finde the Å¿ayde houÅ¿es by your table in the faÅ¿hion and maner as hath bene Å¿ayde before of the time after none. And if you do not preciÅ¿ely finde the Å¿ayde time, you Å¿hal then take the moÅ¿t nereÅ¿t, or elles if ye will be Å¿o curious that you will haue the extreme certaintie, you Å¿hall take the houÅ¿es whiche are right with the time that is nexte leÅ¿Å¿er then yours, and then with the minutes whiche do reÅ¿te, and the difference of euerye houÅ¿e, you Å¿hall take the parte proportionall in minutes, or in degrees and minutes, by the aboue Å¿ayde table quatuor minutorum temporis, as it hath ben declared and done of the time of the iuÅ¿te none. The whiche partes proportionals you Å¿hall adde vnto the Å¿aide houÅ¿es, for to haue them more preciÅ¿ely. And for the more better vnderÅ¿tanding, you may examine the example whiche foloweth, calculated for 8 houres in the morninge, which are foure before none of the aboue
Å¿ayde laÅ¿t day of June 1540, and for the Å¿aide latitude of 48 degrees, the Å¿unne beinge then in the 17 degree and 21 minutes of the Å¿igne of Cancer.

div.head: Â¶ Of the Å¿ixe houÅ¿es occidentals, oppoÅ¿ites, or contrarye vnto the Å¿ixe goinge before.
div.p:
VUhan you haue the Å¿ixe honÅ¿es orientals aboue Å¿aid, by one of the thre rules or differences aforeÅ¿ayd, you Å¿hall haue then forthwith the Å¿ixe houÅ¿es
occidentalles, by the Å¿ignes and degrees oppoÅ¿ites, for becauÅ¿e that euerye greate circle deuideth in the Å¿phere all other great circles, into two halues, or equall partes. As if the .x. houÅ¿e beginne at the xvii. degree of PiÅ¿ces, the fourth houÅ¿e (whiche is his oppoÅ¿ite, and deuided by a lyke circle) Å¿hall beginne at the. xvii, degre of Uirgo, whiche is oppoÅ¿ite vnto the Å¿aide Å¿igne of PiÅ¿ces, and Å¿o it is to be vnderÅ¿tand of all others, by meanes wher â¢ of no man doth deÅ¿cribe in the tables any other but the Å¿ixe houÅ¿es orientalles. For it Å¿uffiÅ¿eth to take the partes oppoÅ¿ites for the Å¿ixe houÅ¿es occidentalles, as we haue Å¿aide here aboue. The houÅ¿es and Å¿ignes oppoÅ¿ites be heare noted to thende you may haue the more eaÅ¿ye vnderÅ¿tanding & vÅ¿e of yâ¢ thinges aboue Å¿aid.

TheÅ¿e thinges thus declared, you Å¿hal make the figure of the. xii houÅ¿es at the houre propoÅ¿ed, and you Å¿hall put at the beouer
all humayne membres, are Å¿uch as do here folowe.

div.head: Â¶ Of the nature and complexion of the lightes, and of the .v. planetes. The .xx. rule.
div.p: AFter this it is neceÅ¿Å¿arye to haue the complexion, vertue, & nature, as well of the Å¿unne & of the mone as of the .v. planetes: the whiche is Å¿uch as foldweth here in orde â¢ .

The Sunne is hote and drie, louing, geuynge lyfe, and lyghte vnto all naturall vertues. And of the members humayne he rulethe the brayne,
the marowe, the Å¿ight, the Å¿yuewes, and generally all the members of the righte parte of the bodye.

Â¶ The mone is colde and moiÅ¿t, louyng, of whome the effectes are manifeÅ¿te, hauing dominatton ouer the Å¿tomacke, the bellye, and of the mother of women, and generally ouer the members of the lefte parte of humayne bodye.

Saturnels colde and drye, enemye of nature, malitious and enuious, deÅ¿troyer of life, and of the bodye he gouerneth the right eare, the milte, and the bladder: and of humors the inclancholye, and parte of the fleume.
Jupiter is hoate and moiÅ¿te, louinge, Å¿anguine, hauinge regarde ouer the langes, the Å¿ides, the griÅ¿tels, and of the Å¿ede or naturall humour of man.

Mars is hote and drye, cruell: and of the humaine bodye is attributed vnto him the lefte eare, the vaynes, the genetories, and of the humors, the choler, and after the opinion of Å¿ome men, he gouerneth the liuer.

Uenus is colde and moyÅ¿te, louinge, flewma â¢ ike, and of the bodye humayne he gouerneth the backe bone, the buttockes: the lower partes of the bellye, the matrice with the mone, and the fa â¢ te and
the Å¿ede, with the Å¿igne of Leo.
And it is to be noted, that Jupiter and Uenus are called good and fortunate, but Jupiter is the greateÅ¿t good fortune and Uenus the leaÅ¿te.
Saturne and Mars are called vnfortunate, or euill fortunes, but Saturne is the greateÅ¿t vnfortunate, and Mars the leaÅ¿te.
The Sunne and the Mone are called meanes, or betwene both, that is to Å¿ay, neither fortunate nor vnfortunate, but indifferent.

NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, Mercury taketh parte alwayes of the nature of the Planete, with the whiche he is cont â¢ yned, or neareÅ¿t vnto: for with the good he is good, principally when he beholdeth him with a trine or Å¿extile aÅ¿pecte. And with the euill he is euill likewiÅ¿e, when he is oppoÅ¿ite or comoyned with them, or when he beholdeth him with a quadrate aÅ¿pecte.

div.head: Of the force and accidentall nature of the aÅ¿pectes. The. 21. â¢ ule.
div.p:
FOr Å¿omuche that the lightes and planets do chaunge their influence accordinge vnto the varietie of the aÅ¿ectes, whiche haue ben declared in the
12. rule, it is conuenient to note the goodnes and malice comming of the Å¿aide aÅ¿pectes, in the faÅ¿hion and maner as foloweth. FyrÅ¿t as touchinge the coniunction (whiche properlye is no aÅ¿pecte) you muÅ¿t note that although the coninnctioÌ be defined to be one, whan the planetes are vnder one like degree of the zodiake, according vnto the longitude of yâ¢ Å¿ame, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e in matter of influence, one planete is Å¿aide to be conioyned with the other, when the one is entred vnder the beames of the other, although that they be not in one like degre, and foreÅ¿eynge that the diÅ¿taunce of the one vnto the other be leÅ¿Å¿e theÌ 12 degres. And the mone or planet Å¿o conioyned wyth the Sunne, is Å¿ayde to be combuÅ¿te by the beames of the Sunne, and Å¿uch coniunction is not proprely a coniunction. And it is to be noted, that when two good planetes are conioyned together, the Å¿ame denoteth manifeÅ¿t amitie and good wyl of the one vnto the other, & encreaÅ¿emente of their goodnes. And the coniunction of the good with the euill, diminiÅ¿heth the malice of the euill planete, and weakeneth Å¿omewhat the goodnes of the good Planete.
As touchinge the oppoÅ¿ition, it is an aÅ¿pect of manifeÅ¿t diÅ¿cord and inimitie.
The quadrate aÅ¿pect is hate and vnper fite inimitie.
The trine aÅ¿pect, Å¿ignifieth perfect and manifeÅ¿t loue of the Planetes.
The Å¿extile aÅ¿pecte, is of hidde & Å¿ecrete beneuolence, and vnperfect amitie.

div.head: Â¶ A declaration of the table of the fixed Å¿terres whiche is in the Ephemerides. The. 22. rule.
div.p:
FOr to knowe the aÅ¿pectes, not onely of the one planet vnto the other, but alÅ¿o of the Å¿ayd planetes & fixed Å¿terres, you haue before the Ephemerides a table intituled, tabula Å¿tellarum fyxarum inÅ¿igniorum. That is to Å¿aye, the table of the mooÅ¿te notable fixed Å¿terres, rectified in the yeare. 1499. The whiche conteineth firÅ¿t of al at the left Å¿ide the names of the moÅ¿t notable fixed Å¿terres, after the members & dominations of the images & con Å¿tellatioÌs in the which they ar brought. The afterward doth containe their loÌgitude. that is to Å¿ay, their true place, & diÅ¿tauÌce froÌ the beginning of Aries. After the which longitude, there foloweth the latitude of the Å¿ayde Å¿terres, which is the deuiatioÌ & diÅ¿tauÌce of yâ¢ Å¿ame fixed Å¿ters
from the zodiake or Ecliptike li â¢ e, or towarde the parte meridionall. ConÅ¿equentlye foloweth the declination of the Å¿ayde Å¿terres from the equinoctial circle, and the difference or denominatioÌ of the Å¿aide declination, that is to be knowen if Å¿he be Å¿eptentrionall by this lettre S. or if Å¿he be meridionall by this lettre M. Afterwarde foloweth the right aÅ¿cention of the Å¿ame Å¿terres, that is to Å¿aye, the arche of the Equinoctiall, beginninge at the diuiÅ¿ion of the Å¿pringe time, and heade of Aries, aÅ¿cending aboue the horizont with the Å¿aide Å¿terres in the right Å¿pheare, and vnder euery merediane. For all m â¢ r â¢ dianes are euery one as a right horizonte, and euery right horizont, is that whiche paÅ¿Å¿eth by the poles of the worlde: finally is noted the greatnes or magnitude, and then the nature of the Å¿ayde Å¿terres referred vnto the Planetes, as the titles, inÅ¿criptions, and characters of the Å¿aide table doth Å¿hewe plainely inough.

div.head: Of the 28 manÅ¿ions or abidinge places of the mone. The 23. rule.
div.p:
COnÅ¿equentlye is to be noted, that euen Å¿o as the Å¿unne doth paÅ¿Å¿e the 12 Å¿ignes of the zodiake in 365 days
and almoÅ¿t 6 houres (whiche maketh the whole yeare) doth cauÅ¿e here below vpon the earth diuers effectes, according vnto the nature of the 12 Å¿ignes, the diuers protection of his beames, and the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition and varietie of inferiour thinges, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e doth the mone, as touchinge his influence, paÅ¿Å¿inge the Å¿aide Zodiake in 27 dayes, and almoÅ¿t 8 houres, accordinge vnto the metinge together of her, with the fixed Å¿terres, whiche are principally in the 12 Å¿ignes of the Zodiake, for Å¿he cauÅ¿eth diuers alterations, and mutations in the elementall region. By menes of the which, and to diÅ¿cerne and knowe the effectes aboueÅ¿aide, the aunciente AÅ¿trologians haue deuided the Å¿ame time of 27 dayes and 8 houres into 28 egall partes, wherof euery one compreheÌdeth 2 â¢ houres and 25 minutes and almooÅ¿te 43 Å¿econdes, and to euerye one of theÅ¿e Å¿ayd 28 partes, do aunÅ¿were 12 degrees, 51 minutes and almooÅ¿t 26 Å¿econdes, the whiche are called the 28 manÅ¿ions of the mone, of the which the diÅ¿tinctions, and beginninges iuÅ¿tified in oure time, and vnto the ninthÅ¿phere, with their natures and properties, ar brought (for more ample eaÅ¿e) into the fourme of a table thus, as foloweth.

div.head: Â¶ A declaration of the table whiche is before the Ephemerides, touching the force, dignitie, exaltation, and other termes or boundes of the Planetes in euery of the 12 Å¿ignes. 24 rule.
div.p:
FOr Å¿o muche that the influences as well of the lightes as of the planets, are augmented, when they be in thoÅ¿e Å¿ignes, in the whiche they haue their force or dignitie as when they be in their propre houÅ¿e, exaltation, triplie â¢
tie, face, or terme prefixed. There is put in the Ephemerides, after the tables of the 12 houÅ¿es, a table of the 12 Å¿ignes, of the dignitie, force, and Å¿trengthe of the Å¿ayde planetes in euery Å¿igne and degree of the Zodiake, of the whiche table, the interpretation is manifeÅ¿t and playne ynough by their titles, inÅ¿criptions, and Å¿ubÅ¿criptions of the Å¿ame. For firÅ¿t of all ioyning vnto the degrees of euery Å¿igne, you haue towarde the righte hande, the depe degres called in latin putei. noted by the letter P. then the degrees fortunates by this Å¿illable For. and the degrees of weakenes and defection of the humaine body, caled AÅ¿emene by this leter A. Then
foloweth the triplicities, faces, & tymes prefixed of the planetesâª marked by the propre characters of them. ConÅ¿equently are noted the degrees maÅ¿culines, by this lettre M. and the feminines by this letter F. The darke and cloudye by this lettre T. The brighte and cleare by this lettre L. and the voyde or emptye by this lettre V. and laÅ¿te of all at the ende and righte Å¿ide of euery Å¿igne, are noted the degrees of the dignities, of the lyghtes and planetes by ordre, beginning at Saturne vnto the mone, and vnto the interÅ¿ections or deuiÅ¿ions of â and â, that is to Å¿aye, of the heade and of the tayle of the dragon of the Å¿ame, as well by their proper characters, as by the nombre of the Å¿aid degrees. And vnderneth euerye Å¿igne, is noted the houÅ¿e and the degree of the exaltation & detriment of the Å¿ayde lightes and planetes, which are thinges neceÅ¿Å¿ary & worthy to be noted of al Å¿uch as do practiÅ¿e the iugemente of the Å¿ters.

div.head: Â¶ Generall and perticuler rules, for to iudge of the mutation and chaunge of the ayre. The 25 rule.
div.p:
TO vnderÅ¿tand and to knowe more eaÅ¿elye how to iudge of the chaungement of the time or wether, and
the mutation of the ayre, it is firÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite to knowe the qualitie and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the foure â¢ artes and Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the yeare, whiche are Å¿uche as foloweth. The Å¿pringe time is hoat and moiÅ¿t, Å¿anguine, and beginneth when the Å¿unne entreth into the Å¿igne of Aries. The Å¿omer is hoate and drye, cholerike, and beginneth when the Sunne entreth into the Å¿igne of Cancer. HarueÅ¿te is colde and dry, melancholike, and beginneth when the Sunne entreth into the Å¿igne of Libra. The winter is colde and moyÅ¿t, fleuma â¢ ike, and beginneth when the Sunne entreth into the Å¿igne of Capricornus. Afterwardes muÅ¿te be knowen and vnderÅ¿tande the natures and affections of the 12 Å¿ignes of the Zodiake, here before expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the ninetenth rule. For y â¢ the planettes (yea thoÅ¿e that be of a hote nature) doo beholde the one the other, or be conioyned together in hoate and drye Å¿ignes, they Å¿hall cauÅ¿e heate and exceÅ¿Å¿e of drougth in Sommer, or elles temperaunce of ayre in Winter. And contrary wiÅ¿e, if the Å¿ayde aÅ¿pectes and coniunctions of the planetes aboueÅ¿ayd, do happen in colde and drye Å¿ygnes, they wyll cauÅ¿e in wynter great Å¿nowes and yet, and in Å¿ommer moderation of the â¢ eate,
and in hoate and moiÅ¿te Å¿ignes, greate aboundaunce of windes. And if this happen in waterye Å¿ignes, they will cauÅ¿e then great haboundaunce of rayne, whiche will make the ayre very intemperate in winter, and of a moderate heate in Å¿oÌ mer. And Å¿o is to be vnderÅ¿tande, and to iudge conformablye of all lyke thinges, accordinge vnto the nature of the planets and Å¿ignes, and theâª qualitie of their aÅ¿pectes. AlÅ¿o hauinge regarde with the Å¿ame, vnto the nature of theâª fixed Å¿terres likewiÅ¿e of them whiche are moÅ¿t n â¢â¢ eÅ¿t vnto the Zodiake. And that not onely in all elections, but alÅ¿o in the mutation of the ayre lykewiÅ¿e, as Å¿halbe perticulerlye recited hereafter.

div.head: Â¶ Other rules, and generall doctrines, for to knowe better and more Å¿urelye to iudge of the varietie of the time and weather, of the alteration of the ayre by the coniunctions, quadratures, & oppoÅ¿itions of the Å¿unne and of the mone.
div.p: FOr as muche as the mutation of the ayre is one of the moÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿aryeÅ¿t thinges, as well for the fruits of the earth, as for the health of the humayne body, and beÅ¿ides that, one of the partes of the iudgement of AÅ¿trologie, more apparent and likeÅ¿t true, I haue Å¿et here all at ones ouer and beÅ¿ides the thinges aboueÅ¿ayd, Å¿ome leÅ¿Å¿ons and notable rules, for to knowe the better and more Å¿brely howe to iudge of the Å¿aid alteration of the ayre.

FirÅ¿t you muÅ¿t diligently note the Å¿inifications and general rules which we haue declared in the rule goinge before, for Å¿omuche that the generall Å¿ignifications do chaunge and Å¿urmount the perticuler vertues, by reaÅ¿on that the greateÅ¿t vertue draweth vnto him the leÅ¿Å¿er, and the leÅ¿Å¿er doth obey vnto the greater, and with this, the perticuler vertues are not of Å¿o great vertue and Å¿trength, as be the generall.

It is then neceÅ¿Å¿arye for all men that wyll iudge of particuler thinges, to conÅ¿ider, and beholde firÅ¿t the thinges whiche be vniuerÅ¿all and generall. As if you wyll prognoÅ¿ticate of the qualitie, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of ani day propoÅ¿ed, you muÅ¿t diligently conÅ¿ider theÅ¿tate or diÅ¿poÅ¿ition
of any day propoÅ¿ed, you muÅ¿t diligentlyâª conÅ¿ider the Å¿tate or diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the time, in the whiche the Å¿ayd daye propoÅ¿ed Å¿hall chaunce or happen. Of the whiche eÅ¿tate and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, you Å¿hal iudge by the lorde of the coniunction, quadratureâª or oppoÅ¿itioÌ preceding of the Sunne and Å¿he mone, and of the Å¿igne where Å¿he is made. The whiche Lorde of the Å¿ayde coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, you Å¿hal knowe by the figure of the auen, that is to Å¿aye of the twelue houÅ¿es, and places of the planetes iuÅ¿tlye verefied at theâª hour of the Å¿ame coniunction, oppoÅ¿ition, or quadrature. Then when you Å¿hal haue the figure of heauen well iuÅ¿tified for the time aboue Å¿ayde of the coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿itioÌ of the Å¿unne and of the mone, you Å¿hall firÅ¿te conÅ¿ider in whiche of the 12 houÅ¿es, and in what Å¿igne Å¿hall fal the Å¿ayd coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, and the Å¿igne and degree aÅ¿cendent, with the Å¿ignes and degrees of the other angles. For theâª planet whiche Å¿hal haue in the Å¿aid places more prerogatiue, force, and domination, Å¿halbe principall lorde of the Å¿aide time and figure, and that whiche Å¿hall haue leaÅ¿te, Å¿halbe participant in the Å¿aid lordeÅ¿hip, & dominatioÌ. And it is to be noted, that the
planet which hath moÅ¿t dominatioÌ vpon the place of the Å¿aid coniunction, oppoÅ¿ition, or quadrature, and vpon the Å¿igne & degree aÅ¿cendant, doth Å¿urmount all the others, and ought to be in this place preferred. Loke then of what nature the planete is which Å¿hall rule in the Å¿aid figure For the vniuerÅ¿al diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the time Å¿hall holde the qualitie of the Å¿aid planet. As if at the time of the Å¿aid coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, Saturne be founde lorde, the time Å¿hall be colde and drye. And if it be Uenus, it Å¿hal be moiÅ¿t, and Å¿o of others, after their nature, and qualitie, excepte the Å¿unne and the mone: for the beÅ¿t aÅ¿trologians, do neuer chuÅ¿e the Å¿unne nor the mone in this place for Lordes nor rulers, for becauÅ¿e that they do eÅ¿teme the 5 planetes to be the onelye moderatours of the time and weather, that is to Å¿aye Saturne, Jupiter, Mars, Uenus, and Mereurye. And not wtoute a cauÅ¿e, in the coniunctioÌ they do chuÅ¿e the Lord of the place of the Å¿aid coniunction. And in the oppoÅ¿itioÌ, the lord of the place of the Å¿ame of the lightes which Å¿halbe aboue thearth, or in thorient preciÅ¿ely, for there is in this place moÅ¿t greateÅ¿t vertu. LikewiÅ¿e in iudging almoÅ¿t as much by the place of the quadrature of the Å¿ayde lightes, for thei take the place of the Å¿ame
light whiche is aboue the horizont, if the other be vnderneth. And if they be bothe aboue, or both vnderneth the Å¿aide horizont (as it chaunceth often times) they take then for the place of the Å¿ayde quadrature, the place of the Å¿ame light whiche is founde to haue moÅ¿t force and dignitie. As if one of the planeties were in one of the angles, or houÅ¿es Å¿uccedinge. and the other in the houÅ¿e fallynge, the Å¿ame whiche is in the Å¿ayde angle, or hooÅ¿e Å¿uccedinge, Å¿halbe preferred before the Å¿ame whiche is in the fallinge houÅ¿e. The whiche force, dignities, and other witneÅ¿Å¿es of the planetes, you Å¿hall extra out of the table, which is expreÅ¿Å¿elye put in the Ephemerides, for the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e, the whiche hath ben Å¿ufficiently declared in the 24 rule. Then when you Å¿hall haue the Lorde and dominatoure at the time of the coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition of the lightes, you Å¿hall fyrÅ¿te note his nature and qualitie. For mooÅ¿t often times the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the tyme Å¿hall reÅ¿emble the Å¿ame. Secondlye you Å¿hall conÅ¿idre the Å¿igne in the whiche is the Å¿ayde lorde and dominatoure, for the time Å¿hall be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed vnto the qualitie of the Å¿ayde Å¿igue. Furthermore, you Å¿hall haue regarde vnto the Å¿igne whiche is
then aÅ¿cendant, and vnto his nature, and of what manÅ¿ion of the mone he is, with out forgettinge the lord of the Å¿ayd Å¿igne aÅ¿cendant. Afterward you Å¿hal take hede and Å¿e whiche planets are in the angles: for thoÅ¿e whiche do occupie the middeÅ¿te of heauen, or the aÅ¿cendant, Å¿hall be better and more Å¿tronger then they whiche Å¿hall be in the angle of the 7 or 4 houÅ¿e. ConÅ¿equentlye you Å¿hall marke, with whiche of the planetes the mone cometh to be conioyned, or in aÅ¿pecte after the â¢â¢ y â¢ d coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition. LikewiÅ¿e you Å¿hall note with which of â¢ he planettes, or notable fyxed Å¿terres, the lord of the Å¿ayd figure i â¢ conioyned, or beheld with any aÅ¿pect. TheÅ¿e thynges thus coÌÅ¿idered, you may bringe to effect, and perfectly iudge as foloweth If the Å¿ayd lord of the coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, be of a moyÅ¿t nature, and the places aboue Å¿ayd and planettes being in them likewiÅ¿e moyÅ¿t: and with this the Å¿ayd lord being conioyned, or in any aÅ¿ â¢â¢â¢â¢ with any moyÅ¿t Å¿terres or planettes. And if the moone after the Å¿ayd coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, come to be conioyned, or in aÅ¿pect with Å¿ome moiÅ¿t planet ioyned therunto that the qualitye of the time be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed
vnto moyÅ¿tnes: if all the thinges aboutÅ¿ayd or the moÅ¿t part of them do tend vnto humiditie, you may gather and iudge that the time Å¿hall be mayÅ¿te, and if they tende vnto drouthe, that it Å¿hall be drye, and if vnto heate that it Å¿halbe hote: and if vnto coldnes, that it Å¿hal be colde: and if there be as many witneÅ¿Å¿es for the one qualitie, as for the other, the time Å¿halbe indifferent, hauing then knowen the general diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the time (as now preÅ¿ently hath â¢ ene Å¿ayd) you Å¿hal diÅ¿cretlye entremingle the applications of the moone vnto the planettes and of the one planet vnto the other, for to indge more certeynly of the perticuler days. And to make an end of this matter, you Å¿hall yet note theÅ¿e .ii. leÅ¿Å¿ons, wherof the firÅ¿te is. that the Å¿ygnyfycation of the tyme thus found as hath bene Å¿ayde aboue, his effect principally Å¿hall appeare, and come forth, when the moone after the coniunction, quadrature, or oppoÅ¿ition, aboueÅ¿ayde Å¿halbe conioyned or comme vnto Å¿ome Å¿tronge planet, with the Å¿ygnificatour of the Å¿ayd time.

div.head: â´ Here folovveth a Å¿ingular treatiÅ¿e of AÅ¿trologie touching the coniunctions of the planettes in euery of the twelue Å¿ignes, and of theyr PrognoÅ¿tications in the reuolutions of yeares.
div.p: IF you deÅ¿ire to knowe euerye yeareâª what thinges Å¿halbe deere, and what good cheape, or of a meane price, Å¿ie what Å¿igne is aÅ¿cendant aboue youre horizont, at the hour that the Å¿unne entreth into the firÅ¿te minute of Aries. div.head: Of the Å¿ignification of the coniuntion of the planets in the Å¿igne of Aries.
div.p: VUhen you Å¿hall haue theÌ made the figure, and found Saturne & Jupiter conioyned together in the Å¿igne of Aries, or the one of them neare vnto the other, they Å¿ignifie Å¿ome newe Å¿ecte to come. div.head: Of the Å¿ignification of the coniunction of the planets in the Å¿igne of Taurus.
div.p:

div.p: If Jupiter, Mars, and Mercurye, be conioyned in the Å¿igne of Uirgo, all the fruytes of the earth Å¿hall periÅ¿he, almoÅ¿t all wholy by the greate aboundaunce of LocuÅ¿tes and greÅ¿hoppers. div.p:
